I. THE ENSUING PROJECT
1. The project aims to improve the well-being of older people in Tonga through a range of
appropriate, safe, and high-quality integrated care services for older people and support to
caregivers. The project will build on the current government-funded homecare program in Tonga
and further expand it to respond to older people’s desire to remain in their homes and community.
For the first time in Tonga, caregivers (who are predominantly women) will be supported to
promote a more sustainable and positive experience in providing care for the older people. The
project outputs include (i) community-based aged care centers established, (ii) aged care services
and programs implemented, and (iii) caregiver support and measures to promote equitable care
responsibility implemented. The project will be aligned with the following impact: healthy aging
among the older people improved. The project will result in the following outcome: integrated aged
care system improved and expanded. The project is estimated to cost $14 million, of which $5
million grant is proposed for funding from Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Special Funds
resources and $5.5 million grant from ADB’s Special Funds resources Asian Development Fund
(ADF) 13 thematic pool. It is expected that the Government of Tonga will allocate an estimated
$0.5 million as counterpart fund. Cofinancing of an indicative $3 million by other development
partners to be administered by ADB will be sought.
II. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Justification
2. The proposed transaction technical assistance (TA) will undertake due diligence and
assessments to assist the government and ADB to develop the proposed Integrated Aged Care
Project. The TA will also build the capacity of the Ministry of Internal Affairs (MIA) and other
relevant government agencies to implement the ensuing project and enhance project readiness
for timely implementation of activities. The TA is justified given the scope of preparatory activities
and specialist nature of skills required for the due diligence and capacity building. The TA is
included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Tonga.1
B. Outputs and Activities
3. Output 1: Review of project design and completion of project due diligence. This
output is expected to review the proposed project components from the ongoing integrated aged
care feasibility study in Tonga and carry out necessary due diligence to ensure its effectiveness
and appropriateness to meet the objective of promoting healthy aging in the country.2 Due
diligence includes poverty, social, and gender analysis; safeguards assessment; procurement
capacity assessment; risk assessment and management plans including anticorruption and
integrity studies; and project implementation arrangements including monitoring and evaluation,
among others. Based on these assessments and analyses, all the required project and linked
documents will be prepared based on ADB requirements and standards.
1  ADB. Forthcoming. Eleven Small Pacific Island Countries: Country Operations Business Plan (2022–2024). Manila. 
2  Feasibility study on aged care in Tonga is being undertaken with funding from the People’s Republic of China Poverty 
Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund administered by the Asian Development Bank under the Strengthening 
Social Protection in ADB. The feasibility study includes economic and financial management assessment, financial 
evaluation, and financial analysis as required by ADB. ADB. 2020. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Social 
Protection in the Pacific. Manila.

2 
4. Output 2: Support to project readiness and project management capacity of the
implementing agency. This output will support project management capacity and readiness.
Specific outputs include assisting the government in undertaking advance actions, such as
preparation for the recruitment of a project management unit, managing the mobilization period,
and preparing draft bidding documents. The capacity of the executing and implementing agencies
and  other  relevant  organizations  for  project  preparation  and  implementation  will  also  be
strengthened. Key activities include (i) assessing the institutional capacity of the implementing
agency and other relevant organizations, if needed, to implement the project; and (ii) organizing
training, capacity building exercises, and activities to address identified gaps and areas requiring
improved capacity.

C. Cost and Financing
6. The TA is estimated $500,000, of which $450,000 will be financed on a grant basis by
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-7). The key expenditure items are listed in
Appendix 1. The government will provide in-kind support in the form of counterpart staff, data,
information, and other in-kind contributions estimated at $50,000. The government was informed
that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.
D. Implementation Arrangements
7. ADB will administer the TA. The Pacific Department’s Social Sectors and Public Sector
Management Division will lead the TA implementation and will select, evaluate, engage, and
supervise the consultants. The Ministry of Finance will be the executing agency and MIA will be
the  implementing  agency.  They  will  provide  necessary  counterpart  support  and  guide  the
implementation of the TA to achieve the TA outputs and desired outcomes within the agreed
implementation period. A Project Steering Committee will be established to guide the project
preparation and due diligence. The project steering committee is envisaged to continue its support
during the implementation of the project.

9. Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following ADB Procurement Policy
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.3 ADB will recruit
international and national individual consultants with an estimated 19.5 person-months for project
design review, due diligence, and project readiness and capacity building. For the simple and
quick deployment, individual procurement consultants may be contracted through the issuing of
call-offs from the Procurement, Portfolio and Financial Management Department’s Framework
Agreement  of  procurement  consultants  (in  Consultant  Management  System:  Framework
Agreement # 100008) who can assist with the full range of procurement activities. All information
on the expertise of empaneled experts and how to issue call-offs is included in the Consultant
Management System record.
